Complex numbers: a review

 

Useful facts and identities:

  • It is well worth memorizing a few commonly seen θθ's (with r=1r=1):
    eiπei2πeiπ2eiπ4eiπ3eiπ6======cosπ+isinπ=−1cos2π+isin2π=1cosπ2+isinπ2=icosπ4+isinπ4=12‾√+12‾√icosπ3+isinπ3=12+3‾√2icosπ6+isinπ6=3‾√2+12ieiπ=cos⁡π+isin⁡π=−1ei2π=cos⁡2π+isin⁡2π=1eiπ2=cos⁡π2+isin⁡π2=ieiπ4=cos⁡π4+isin⁡π4=12+12ieiπ3=cos⁡π3+isin⁡π3=12+32ieiπ6=cos⁡π6+isin⁡π6=32+12i

  • Useful trig identities for quantum computing:
    sin(−θ)cos(−θ)sin2θ+cos2θsin(θ1+θ2)cos(θ1+θ2)=====−sinθcosθ1sinθ1cosθ2+cosθ1sinθ2cosθ1cosθ2−sinθ1sinθ2sin⁡(−θ)=−sin⁡θcos⁡(−θ)=cos⁡θsin2⁡θ+cos2⁡θ=1sin⁡(θ1+θ2)=sin⁡θ1cos⁡θ2+cos⁡θ1sin⁡θ2cos⁡(θ1+θ2)=cos⁡θ1cos⁡θ2−sin⁡θ1sin⁡θ2

  • From which
    cos(2θ)sin(2θ)==2cos2θ−12sinθcosθcos⁡(2θ)=2cos2⁡θ−1sin⁡(2θ)=2sin⁡θcos⁡θ
 

Problem:
Simplify i15i15

Solution:

i15=i⋅i14=i⋅(i2)7=i(−1)7=−ii15=i⋅i14=i⋅(i2)7=i(−1)7=−i
 

Problem:
Simplify i−13−2ii−13−2i into a+iba+ib form.

Solution:
Use the division trick of multiplying and dividing by the conjugate of the denominator:

i−13−2i====i−13−2i3+2i3+2i3i+2i2−3−2i32+22−5+i13−513+113ii−13−2i=i−13−2i3+2i3+2i=3i+2i2−3−2i32+22=−5+i13=−513+113i
 

Problem:
Calculate Re ((3+2i)(1−i))Re ((3+2i)(1−i))

Solution:

(3+2i)(1−i)=3−3i+2i−2i2=5−i(3+2i)(1−i)=3−3i+2i−2i2=5−i
Thus, Re ((3+2i)(1−i))=5Re ((3+2i)(1−i))=5
 

Problem:
Compute (1+i)8(1+i)8

Solution:
Instead of laboriously multiplying, we'll write 1+i1+i in polar form, where powers are straightforward:

1+i==2‾√(12‾√+12‾√i)2‾√eiπ41+i=2(12+12i)=2eiπ4
Thus,
(1+i)8====(2‾√eiπ4)8(2‾√)8e2πi2416(1+i)8=(2eiπ4)8=(2)8e2πi=24=16
 

Problem:
Prove, for complex numbers z1,z2z1,z2:

  1. (z1+z2)∗=z∗1+z∗2(z1+z2)∗=z1∗+z2∗
  2. (z1z2)∗=z∗1z∗2(z1z2)∗=z1∗z2∗
  3. |z1z2|=|z1||z2||z1z2|=|z1||z2|

Solution:
Let z1=a1+ib1z1=a1+ib1 and z2=a2+ib2z2=a2+ib2.

  1. (z1+z2)∗=(a1+ib1+a2+ib2)∗=a1+a2−i(b1+b2)=(a1−ib1)+(a2−ib2)=z∗1+z∗2(z1+z2)∗=(a1+ib1+a2+ib2)∗=a1+a2−i(b1+b2)=(a1−ib1)+(a2−ib2)=z1∗+z2∗
  2. (z1z2)∗=((a1+ib1)(a2+ib2))∗=(a1a2−b1b2+(a1b1+a2b1)i)∗=a1a2−b1b2−(a1b1+a2b1)i)=a1a2−b1b2−(a1b1+a2b1)i)=(a1−ib1)(a2−ib2)=z∗1z∗2(z1z2)∗=((a1+ib1)(a2+ib2))∗=(a1a2−b1b2+(a1b1+a2b1)i)∗=a1a2−b1b2−(a1b1+a2b1)i)=a1a2−b1b2−(a1b1+a2b1)i)=(a1−ib1)(a2−ib2)=z1∗z2∗
  3. |z1z2|2=(z1z2)(z1z2)∗=(z1z2)(z∗1z∗2)=(z1z∗z)(z2z∗2)=|z1|2|z2|2|z1z2|2=(z1z2)(z1z2)∗=(z1z2)(z1∗z2∗)=(z1zz∗)(z2z2∗)=|z1|2|z2|2
    Since magnitudes are positive real numbers, |z1z2|=|z1||z2||z1z2|=|z1||z2|.
 

Complex vectors with Dirac notation

 

Problem:
With ∣∣u⟩=(1,2−i,3i),∣∣v⟩=(2,1,i),∣∣w⟩=(1,−2,3)|u⟩=(1,2−i,3i),|v⟩=(2,1,i),|w⟩=(1,−2,3), and α=(2−3i),β=−1α=(2−3i),β=−1, calculate

  1. the vectors α∣∣v⟩,∣∣αv⟩,⟨αu∣∣,α∗⟨u∣∣α|v⟩,|αv⟩,⟨αu|,α∗⟨u|
  2. the numbers ⟨u|v⟩,⟨v|u⟩,⟨v|u⟩∗⟨u|v⟩,⟨v|u⟩,⟨v|u⟩∗, and compare the first and third.
  3. the matrix ∣∣u⟩⟨v∣∣|u⟩⟨v|, the matrix-vector product ∣∣u⟩⟨v∣∣∣∣w⟩|u⟩⟨v||w⟩, and the scalar-vector product ⟨v|w⟩∣∣u⟩⟨v|w⟩|u⟩, and compare the latter two results.
  4. ∣∣∣∣u⟩∣∣2,⟨u|u⟩||u⟩|2,⟨u|u⟩

Solution:

  1. Since ∣∣v⟩|v⟩ is already a column vector
    ∣∣αv⟩=α∣∣v⟩=(2−3i)⎡⎣⎢⎢21i⎤⎦⎥⎥=⎡⎣⎢⎢−3i−8i9+5i⎤⎦⎥⎥|αv⟩=α|v⟩=(2−3i)[21i]=[−3i−8i9+5i]
    Next,
    αu=(2−3i)⎡⎣⎢⎢21i⎤⎦⎥⎥=⎡⎣⎢⎢4−6i2−3i3+2i⎤⎦⎥⎥αu=(2−3i)[21i]=[4−6i2−3i3+2i]
    and so
    ⟨αu∣∣=[4+6i2+3i3−2i]⟨αu|=[4+6i2+3i3−2i]
    If, on the other hand, we conjugate and then scalar-multiply:
    α∗⟨u∣∣=(2+3i)[21−i]=[4+6i2+3i3−2i]α∗⟨u|=(2+3i)[21−i]=[4+6i2+3i3−2i]
    as expected.
  2. First,
    ⟨u|v⟩=[12+i−3i]⎡⎣⎢⎢21i⎤⎦⎥⎥=2+(2+i)−3i2=7+i⟨u|v⟩=[12+i−3i][21i]=2+(2+i)−3i2=7+i
    Next
    ⟨v|u⟩=[21−i]⎡⎣⎢⎢12−i3i⎤⎦⎥⎥=7−i⟨v|u⟩=[21−i][12−i3i]=7−i
    and so
    ⟨v|u⟩∗=7+i=⟨u|v⟩⟨v|u⟩∗=7+i=⟨u|v⟩
  3. First
    ∣∣u⟩⟨v∣∣=⎡⎣⎢⎢24−2i6i12−i3i−i−1−2i3⎤⎦⎥⎥|u⟩⟨v|=[21−i4−2i2−i−1−2i6i3i3]
    Multiplying this matrix into ∣∣w⟩|w⟩ gives
    ∣∣u⟩⟨v∣∣∣∣w⟩=⎡⎣⎢⎢24−2i6i12−i3i−i−1−2i3⎤⎦⎥⎥⎡⎣⎢⎢1−23⎤⎦⎥⎥=⎡⎣⎢⎢−3i−3−6i9⎤⎦⎥⎥|u⟩⟨v||w⟩=[21−i4−2i2−i−1−2i6i3i3][1−23]=[−3i−3−6i9]
    Next,
    ⟨v|w⟩=[21−i]⎡⎣⎢⎢1−23⎤⎦⎥⎥=−3i⟨v|w⟩=[21−i][1−23]=−3i
    Multiplying into ∣∣u⟩|u⟩ gives
    ⟨v|w⟩∣∣u⟩=−3i⎡⎣⎢⎢12−i3i⎤⎦⎥⎥=⎡⎣⎢⎢−3i−3−6i9⎤⎦⎥⎥⟨v|w⟩|u⟩=−3i[12−i3i]=[−3i−3−6i9]
    Thus, we see that
    (∣∣u⟩⟨v∣∣)∣∣w⟩=∣∣u⟩(⟨v|w⟩)=(⟨v|w⟩)∣∣u⟩(|u⟩⟨v|)|w⟩=|u⟩(⟨v|w⟩)=(⟨v|w⟩)|u⟩
    since ⟨v|w⟩⟨v|w⟩ is a number.
  4. Clearly
    ∣∣∣∣u⟩∣∣2=|1|2+|2+i|2+|−3i|2=15||u⟩|2=|1|2+|2+i|2+|−3i|2=15
    and
    ⟨u|u⟩=[12+i−3i]⎡⎣⎢⎢12−i3i⎤⎦⎥⎥=15⟨u|u⟩=[12+i−3i][12−i3i]=15
    As expected, they should be the same.
 

Inner products, projectors, Hermitians and unitaries

 

Problem:
Thus far we've seen projectors defined with unit-length vectors, as ∣∣v⟩v|v⟩v, and the completeness relation for an orthonormal basis as ∑i∣∣vi⟩vi=I∑i|vi⟩vi=I. Does the completeness relation work for non-unit length vectors? If not, what is the tweak needed to make it work?

Solution:
Consider, for example, ∣∣v1⟩=(1,1),∣∣v2⟩=(−1,1)|v1⟩=(1,1),|v2⟩=(−1,1). Both are not unit-length since

⟨v1|v1⟩⟨v2|v2⟩==22⟨v1|v1⟩=2⟨v2|v2⟩=2
The sum
∣∣v1⟩⟨v1∣∣+∣∣v2⟩⟨v2∣∣=[11][11]+[−11][−11]=[1111]+[1−1−11]=[2002]≠I|v1⟩⟨v1|+|v2⟩⟨v2|=[11][11]+[−11][−11]=[1111]+[1−1−11]=[2002]≠I
But it appears that scaling by the length (in this case, 2) will result in II. We can formalize this as follows.

Let ∣∣v1⟩,…,∣∣vn⟩|v1⟩,…,|vn⟩ be an non-unit length but orthogonal basis and ktuktu be a vector. that we express as:

∣∣u⟩=∑iαi∣∣vi⟩|u⟩=∑iαi|vi⟩
where, as usual, each αiαi is obtained by multiplying each side by ⟨vi∣∣⟨vi|:
⟨vi|u⟩=αi⟨vi|vi⟩⟨vi|u⟩=αi⟨vi|vi⟩
(all other inner products are zero). And so,
αi=⟨vi|u⟩⟨vi|vi⟩=⟨vi|u⟩|vi|2αi=⟨vi|u⟩⟨vi|vi⟩=⟨vi|u⟩|vi|2
Now return to the expression of ∣∣u⟩|u⟩:
∣∣u⟩====∑iαi∣∣vi⟩∑i⟨vi|u⟩|vi|2∣∣vi⟩∑i1|vi|2∣∣vi⟩⟨vi∣∣∣∣u⟩(∑i1|vi|2∣∣vi⟩⟨vi∣∣)∣∣u⟩|u⟩=∑iαi|vi⟩=∑i⟨vi|u⟩|vi|2|vi⟩=∑i1|vi|2|vi⟩⟨vi||u⟩=(∑i1|vi|2|vi⟩⟨vi|)|u⟩
Thus,
∑i1|vi|2∣∣vi⟩⟨vi∣∣=I∑i1|vi|2|vi⟩⟨vi|=I
Which is the desired completeness relation. The real goal of this exercise is to get more comfortable with Dirac notation and "moving" the scalar to reformulate in terms of the outerproduct.
 

Problem:
This problem is intended to increase familiarity with Dirac symbols. Suppose ∣∣0⟩,∣∣1⟩,…,∣∣N−1⟩|0⟩,|1⟩,…,|N−1⟩ are NN basis vectors and that ∣∣u⟩,∣∣v⟩|u⟩,|v⟩ are two vectors in the same space expressed as

∣∣u⟩∣∣v⟩==α0∣∣0⟩+…+αN−1∣∣N−1⟩β0∣∣0⟩+…+βN−1∣∣N−1⟩|u⟩=α0|0⟩+…+αN−1|N−1⟩|v⟩=β0|0⟩+…+βN−1|N−1⟩
Show that
⟨u|v⟩=∑i=0N−1α∗iβi⟨u|v⟩=∑i=0N−1αi∗βi

Solution:

⟨xα0∣∣0⟩+…+αN−1∣∣N−1⟩∣∣β0∣∣0⟩+…+βN−1∣∣N−1⟩⟩=β0⟨xα0∣∣0⟩+…+αN−1∣∣N−1⟩∣∣0⟩+…+βN−1⟨xα0∣∣0⟩+…+αN−1∣∣N−1⟩∣∣N−1⟩=β0(xα∗0⟨0∣∣+…+α∗N−1⟨N−1∣∣)∣∣0⟩+…+βN−1(xα∗0⟨0∣∣+…+α∗N−1⟨N−1∣∣)∣∣N−1⟩=β0α∗0⟨0|0⟩+…+βN−1α∗N−1⟨N−1|N−1⟩=α∗0β0+…+α∗N−1βN−1⟨xα0|0⟩+…+αN−1|N−1⟩|β0|0⟩+…+βN−1|N−1⟩⟩=β0⟨xα0|0⟩+…+αN−1|N−1⟩|0⟩+…+βN−1⟨xα0|0⟩+…+αN−1|N−1⟩|N−1⟩=β0(xα0∗⟨0|+…+αN−1∗⟨N−1|)|0⟩+…+βN−1(xα0∗⟨0|+…+αN−1∗⟨N−1|)|N−1⟩=β0α0∗⟨0|0⟩+…+βN−1αN−1∗⟨N−1|N−1⟩=α0∗β0+…+αN−1∗βN−1
Notice that, in the first line, for additional clarity, we have left the vector form in the left (conjugated) side of an inner-product:
⟨xα0∣∣0⟩+…+αN−1∣∣N−1⟩∣∣β0∣∣0⟩+…+βN−1∣∣N−1⟩⟩⟨xα0|0⟩+…+αN−1|N−1⟩|β0|0⟩+…+βN−1|N−1⟩⟩
Here, the intention is to allow anything to sit inside the inner-product, and to simplify it at the right time.
 

Problem:
Since inner products are computed often, let's do another example problem. Show that

∣∣u⟩∣∣u⊥⟩==i3‾√∣∣0⟩−2‾√3‾√∣∣1⟩−2‾√3‾√∣∣0⟩−i3‾√∣∣1⟩|u⟩=i3|0⟩−23|1⟩|u⊥⟩=−23|0⟩−i3|1⟩
are a 2D basis, and then compute the coefficients when expressing ∣∣+⟩|+⟩ in this basis.

Solution:
First, let's show they are orthogonal and of unit-length.

⟨u∣∣u⊥⟩===⟨x−i3‾√⟨0∣∣−2‾√3‾√⟨1∣∣∣∣∣−2‾√3‾√∣∣0⟩+i3‾√∣∣1⟩⟩i2‾√3⟨0|0⟩−i2‾√3⟨1|1⟩0⟨u|u⊥⟩=⟨x−i3⟨0|−23⟨1||−23|0⟩+i3|1⟩⟩=i23⟨0|0⟩−i23⟨1|1⟩=0
Unit-length:
⟨u|u⟩===⟨x−i3‾√⟨0∣∣−2‾√3‾√⟨1∣∣∣∣∣i3‾√∣∣0⟩−2‾√3‾√∣∣1⟩⟩−i23+231⟨u|u⟩=⟨x−i3⟨0|−23⟨1||i3|0⟩−23|1⟩⟩=−i23+23=1
Next, the coefficients:
⟨u|+⟩=⟨x−i3‾√⟨0∣∣−2‾√3‾√⟨1∣∣∣∣∣12‾√∣∣0⟩+12‾√∣∣1⟩⟩=−2‾√6‾√−i6‾√⟨u|+⟩=⟨x−i3⟨0|−23⟨1||12|0⟩+12|1⟩⟩=−26−i6
and
⟨u⊥∣∣+⟩=⟨x−2‾√3‾√⟨0∣∣−i3‾√⟨1∣∣∣∣∣12‾√∣∣0⟩+12‾√∣∣1⟩⟩=−2‾√6‾√−i6‾√⟨u⊥|+⟩=⟨x−23⟨0|−i3⟨1||12|0⟩+12|1⟩⟩=−26−i6
Check:
∣∣⟨u|+⟩∣∣2+∣∣⟨u⊥∣∣+⟩∣∣2=1+26+1+26=1|⟨u|+⟩|2+|⟨u⊥|+⟩|2=1+26+1+26=1
(See Proposition 2.9). Thus,
∣∣+⟩=⟨u|+⟩∣∣u⟩+⟨u⊥∣∣+⟩∣∣u⊥⟩=(−2‾√6‾√−i6‾√)∣∣u⟩+(−2‾√6‾√−i6‾√)∣∣u⊥⟩|+⟩=⟨u|+⟩|u⟩+⟨u⊥|+⟩|u⊥⟩=(−26−i6)|u⟩+(−26−i6)|u⊥⟩
